newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 24.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 24.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Friday:
* PepsiCo Inc announces plans to spin off its multibillion dollar restaurant business into a publicly traded fast-food company that would be second only to McDonald's Corp.
* After peaking at 6,900, the Dow Jones industrial average takes a 94.28-point plunge to close at 6,755.75 in the busiest trading day in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.
* The stock of Texas Instruments rose 11 percent after the company announces plans to sell its notebook computer business to Acer Inc.
* Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co says it will buy control of Amphenol Corp, the second largest maker of coaxial cable, for about $1.2 billion cash.
* Xerox Corp reports better than expected earnings and says it will sell its Coregis insurance unit to General Electric and its Apprise computer services unit to Anderson Consulting.
* Boeing and McDonnell Douglas shares fall after the companies' fourth quarter earnings come in below Wall Street's expectations.
* Sears posts a 25 percent increase in earnings on strong sales and an increase in credit card revenue.
* Delta Air Lines says its second quarter earnings rose 79 percent, but Southwest Airlines reported lower fourth quarter earnings that it attributed in part to higher fuel prices.
* Sony Corp says it may add a second headquarters in New York to support its U.S. operations.
* Bonds traded in a narrow range, and the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.86 percent from 6.82 percent.
* Outgoing secretary of HUD Henry Cisneros accepts a job as president and chief operating officer of Univision Communications, the largest Spanish television broadcaster in the U.S.
* Last weekend's winter freeze in Florida could lead to price fruit and vegetable price hikes across the nation.
* Sega Enterprises said it would buy Japanese toy company Bandai Co Ltd in a stock swap worth about $1 billion, becoming the world's largest toy and video-game company.
* A divorce case involving a General Electric executive worth $100 million raises questions about how much a spouse is entitled to claim.
* Gyrations in the Tokyo stock market spur worries about the Japanese economy.
* Christie's, the auction house, is negotiating a move into a 300,000-square-foot space at Rockefeller Center, where it would consolidate its warehouses, offices and auction space.
* The latest stock market-Super Bowl theory favors the New England Patriots over the Green Bay Packers. -- Market Place.
